job_title: Admissions Counselor in San Diego, CA
pros: - Remote/hybrid work - Decent benefits package - Autonomy

job_title: Manager in San Diego, CA
pros: APA Clinical programs are well respected and provide valuable preparation and experiences for graduates. Faculty are well connected to the profession and many are thought leaders who actively publish and contribute scholarly works. Innovative delivery models for education and counseling programs meet the needs of students and employers. Senior leadership is dedicated to sharing information to employees regarding strategic planning and real-time operational outcomes. CEO has open door policy.
cons: Higher education as a sector overall is in a period of dramatic change (and that change is difficult for some to adapt to), which makes for grumbling amongst employees. Limited opportunities for internal advancement in specific roles or locations due to small size of the university overall if people are location bound or narrowly set on a specific title for advancement.

job_title: Assistant Professor in San Diego, CA
pros: Interesting work Doing research Mentoring students Smart and friendly colleagued
cons: Low salaries Lack of resources

job_title: Admissions Counselor in San Diego, CA
pros: Holidays and PTO; collaborative and team-oriented culture; work-life balance; decent benefits
cons: Low pay and little room for growth; no performance-based reviews or evaluations to contribute to career mobility

job_title: Senior Admissions Counselor in San Diego, CA
pros: Good Culture, Team Environment, Paid Time Off, Holidays off, Work like balance
cons: Little Upward Mobility, Not Performance based

review_title: Great people, terrible advancement opportunities and lack of innovation
job_title: Admissions Counselor in San Diego, CA
pros:
- Management is fair, intelligent, capable, and motivating. Direct management cares about you and gets the most out of teams with great support. They treat you like an individual and care about your needs.
- Work-life balance is expected
- Job is stable and upper management has financially made sure the university is growing and improving.
cons:
- 3% QOL pay raise every year where the main campus is in San Diego. No performance-based reviews or evaluations leading to opportunity or gains.
- 2-week, federal minimum vacation time per year until your third year. Larger universities start at three.
- No professional development opportunities outside of job area. Difficult to gauge what is required to advance. 
- More job responsibilities and volume added without any incentive. 
- Lack of diversity in upper management. Diversity initiatives seem like smoke and mirrors. Difficult to see “impact” from the bottom of the pyramid.
- Little innovation in modality of courses and student services. Alliant can be seen (and understandably so) as a “diploma mill” because there are a lot of students and not often a lot of individual support. Also, there is very little rigor in the admissions process; they’ll let just about anyone in to most programs and the requirements are bare bones. Makes it difficult to stand behind the product.
- It’s all about the bottom line. They’re a “public benefit” corporation but it’s smoke and mirrors. There is no benefit to the immediate community that Alliant provides around their campuses that doesn’t come at an exorbitant price (and even then the quality is questionable).

review_title: This institution, in spite of its "Impact Values", tolerates academic bullying.
job_title: Student Services in San Diego, CA
pros: Dedicated and cooperative Staff who put students first.
cons: Institutional awareness and tolerance of academic bullying by Senior Leadership that left me with PTSD.

job_title: Admissions Counselor in San Diego, CA
pros: Gaining professional experience and expanding my circle
cons: I can not think of any cons at this time. Everything has been good

job_title: Psychologist in San Diego, CA
pros: good place to work at

job_title: Human Resources Associate in San Diego, CA

job_title: Admissions Counselor in San Diego, CA
pros: People that genuinely care about you. Little micro managing. Flexible work schedule. Manager is great at maximizing your skill set and believing in you.
cons: Little opportunities for advancement. No performance pay. Little opportunity for growth despite exemplary performance. Only way to get paid more is to get promoted.

review_title: Strong Values and Commitment to Community
job_title: General Counsel in San Diego, CA
pros: Excellent leadership, Teamwork, Inclusive and Collaborative

job_title: Marketing Director in San Diego, CA
pros: Great colleagues and leadership, an excellent and shared perspective on the mission of the university and it's programs, and a beautiful campus.
cons: Nothing that really stands out.

job_title: Regional Director of Admissions in Irvine, CA

job_title: Administrative Coordinator in San Diego, CA
pros: Good benefits and time off
cons: Always changing, no consistency in policies or processes, communication from top down is lacking

job_title: Marketing/Admissions in San Francisco, CA
pros: There are wonderful folks at Alliant, especially among the faculty. They are an amazing collection of humane and progressive people. The benefits are excellent, and you won't feel embarrassed if you come and go at reasonable work hours - no one is in the office over the weekend. The San Francisco office is in a nicely remodeled space and pleasant as non-profits go.
cons: If you are expecting to be rewarded for performance, forget it. There's no strategic planning process and the place is run like a monarchy. There's no accountability at the top level, and no VP or dean is ever punished for overspending or underachieving. Although Alliant calls itself a  professional practice university, there's no professional respect for staff or practitioners - staff are definitely second-class citizens. Faculty, or at least core faculty, do get some respect, but salaries are low. High achieving staff are "rewarded" with ever-expanding work loads and burn out is high. There's no professional development and no promotional path.

job_title: Adjunct Faculty in Rancho San Diego, CA
pros: Students are great, small classes
cons: The IT system can be a challenge

review_title: Worst place I've ever worked at in my life.
job_title: in San Diego, CA
pros: Benefits are decent compared to other private universities.
cons: So full of politics.  Fear rules this place. All the back stabbing that goes around here will make Brutus like pretty good. People talk alot here and don't get anything done. It feels like everyone is just doing enough and waiting for the next chip to fall or waiting to find another job. Lack of respect leads to low moral which leads very disappointed employees.

job_title: Coordinator in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Paycheck that, despite my continual expectations, never bounced. That is all.
cons: There's not enough room here to explain everything. Alliant is where careers comes to stall and eventually wither away until you are left with nothing but a dried out husk of something that may have once been associated with the words "ambition", "innovation", or "integrity". Be prepared to do the work of 2-3 employees with many years in between any type of pay raise. Watch as students pay exorbitant costs for the "privilege" of being taught by therapy-burnouts, with only a smattering of competent/caring faculty to sweeten the taste of this outrageous scam of a school. I saw co-workers fired on obvious trumped up accusations, berated by superiors to the point of emotional abuse affecting their health, and a revolving door of program directors and competent faculty who left before you could even learn their last names. I have nothing but the utmost respect for the rank and file staff. They are (mostly) hard working, caring, salt of the earth people. Unfortunately, they also have little drive and what self-belief and dreams they may have once had were grinded out of them overtime by a ruthless culture of keeping the con going. Unless you are starving or have a STRONG exit plan and just need some quick professional experience....turn the other way and never look back at this  "school"

review_title: interesting, challenging, developmental work-- and I like what I do.
job_title: Assistant Professor in San Diego, CA
pros: flexibility and career building opportunity, great students, love the work
cons: employees have their separate lives--little cohesiveness among the employees. top mgmt  has made tough calls and done some good things, but are still not respected because their views seem so conservative and they are several years behind the curve in adapting to competitors

review_title: Unfair and bias tactics run from administration to campus management no matter your experience or skillset.
job_title: Academic Affairs in San Francisco, CA
pros: Their retirement pkg is good I would imagine
cons:
Pay and benefits for new comers are terrible here
President (who is the by the way?) makes six digits but does nothing for his staff and people 
Women heavy (too many women that cause drama and are gabby Bettys and don't work) 
Technology is backwards here which causes work processes to halt
Network/Internet out 40% of the time 
Lack of sensitivity and diversity training 
Ethics and confidentially don't exist here 
HR, huh? HR doesn't know what's happening half the time
Turn over -turn over -turn over -turn over
Senior Faculty and Program directors do their own thing making it difficult to work in unity - the student suffers

review_title: Thank my lucky stars I left
job_title: Academic and Administrative Support II in San Francisco, CA
pros: A Paycheck and Benefits. Nice area of San Francisco to work in. Determined co-workers
cons: Where do I begin... toxic work environment. No performance reviews. Lack of communication from the top down. No clear expectations for the positions and division of labor. CEO and VPs are ineffectual. Would rather overload current employees rather than hire new ones. Lack of resources. Lack of training on information systems and basic functionality of the position. No career development, no professional development, and no clear career path. No raises. Do yourself a favor and look over these reviews carefully and ask yourself is it really worth the aggravation to work here for a low paying position?

job_title: in San Francisco, CA
pros: Good benefits, individual schools within the university are pleasant enough to work within, so long as you don't need to touch larger University resources/structure.
cons:
Alliant is simply the most frustrating institution I've ever worked for. It's as if the directors and VPs want to run Alliant into the ground. There is incredibly high turnover in the executive/director positions, and each sea-change sees a complete 180 of the previous regime's goals and direction. Also, since this company was purchased by Bertelsmann, I've seen an INCREDIBLE profit-minded focus, which has hurt the company, moral, and ultimately, student experience.

Those in charge are currently liquidating as much as they can of the organizational assets for short-term profits at the expense of long-term health. It's a goddamn shame seeing what they are doing.

review_title: People here have the heart of gold
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Bowie, MD
pros: Staff are invested in each other and providing students with the best service.  Students are passionate and driven to succeed in life.  Diversity is another strength of this university.  Staff perks were great such as benefits and time off.  Flexibility is also a plus working here.
cons: Transparency and communication were two challenges occurring at this university.  Sometimes major changes were announced with little or no input from individuals who were affected by the changes.

review_title: I'm pretty sure 1 star is generous for this place.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Diego, CA
pros: Health and retirement benefits were the only reasons to stay.
cons: EVERYTHING! Seriously, how much longer are they going to keep the president? CSPP is trying to pull out of the place, it is a big joke. No one is happy, every employee I know is spending their free time, and not so free time browsing Monster and CareerBuilder. I'm not sure there is anyone else I respect working there anymore. They all have left dodge as soon as they could. Be careful, they'll lay you off and have you reapply for your job, dump 20-50% more work on you and cut your salary. It's the most shady disheartening place I have ever experienced.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Diego, CA
pros: ummmm..... They say I have to enter 5 words. I am at a loss.
cons: Sold out to a for profit, provost not capable of making hard decisions, where is the president? constant turnover. Alliant must be a coffin because they sure are burying it. Faculty love to pat themselves on the back teaching 20 year old theories. We needed a takeover but all we got was a conglomerate who already fired the people who created their subsidiary company for lack of results and then just placed them as Alliant employees. It's a real joke.

job_title: Department Student Assistant in Fresno, CA

cons: Limitations included: lack of funding, lack of professional internship, residency with professional organizations, and/or employment placement.

job_title: Staff Member in Los Angeles, CA

Some faculty/staff have been here WAY TOO LONG and arent  affective in their jobs anymore or think they're so important and untouchable that they act unreasonably.

review_title: An organization dedicated to true Impact
